data.name: Extreme Large Numbers Vocabulary  ±((1e+66)-1) in English
data.description:
Extreme Large Numbers Vocabulary ±((1e+66)-1) in English

In this Kata You will Create a function that receives a integer or a integer string from ±((1e+66)-1) or in english (negative or positive nine hundred and ninety nine vigintillion nine...) as input and converts it to spoken english words.

Inputs the function should support:
[✓] numbers in the range of ±((1e+66)-1) including: ±Infinity and ±0
[✓] all decimals including: Infinity followed by a decimal(although not a real number)
[✓] negative vs positive numbers inluding: +0||0 vs -0
#inputs > ±((1e+15)+1) will be sent as a integer string (this is a clue!)
    Rules for Outputs:
  • Numbers between 20 and 99 use hyphens (unless the ones place is a 0)
    • Example: 45 return 'forty-five'
    • Example: 21 return 'twenty-one'
    • Example: 20 return 'twenty'

  • Use the word 'and' to separate the tens space from the hundreds space in each period (grouping of 3 or less numbers)
    • Example: 111 return 'one hundred and eleven'
    • Example: 101 return 'one hundred and one'

  • Use a space to separate all other words.
    • Example: 123 return 'one hundred and twenty-three'

  • the word 'and' for numbers over 1000 is used to separate the tens and ones space from the lowest number
    • Example: 1001 return 'one thousand and one'
    • Example: 1000001 return 'one million and one'
    • Example: 1000011 return 'one million and eleven'
    • Example: 1000111 return 'one million one hundred and eleven'
    • Example: 1011001 return 'one million eleven thousand and one'
    • Example: 1011011 return 'one million eleven thousand and eleven'
    • Example: 1011111 return 'one million eleven thousand one hundred and eleven'
    • Example: 1109110 return 'one million one hundred and nine thousand one hundred and ten'

  • Number 0 should return 'zero'
    • Example: 0 return 'zero'

  • Number Infinity should return 'infinity'
    • Example: Infinity return 'infinity'

  • for negative integers return the word 'negative' before the number
    • Example: -20 return 'negative twenty'
    • Example: -20.012 return 'negative twenty point zero one two'
    • Example: -1 return 'negative one'
    • Example: -Infinity return 'negative infinity'
    • Example: -0 return 'negative zero'

  • for decimal numbers return the numbers to the left of the decimal then the word 'point' and then the numbers to the right of the decimal each digit at a time.
    • Example: 1.23 return 'one point two three'
    • Example: -1.23 return 'negative one point two three'
    • Example: 0.23 return 'zero point two three'
    • Example:'Infinity.23' return 'infinity point two three' (although not a real number)
    • Example: -0.23 return 'negative zero point two three'

  • Non-Numbers should throw a error
    • Example: '123a45' throw error
    • Example: 'bcd' throw error
    • Example: '.' throw error

  • Integer Strings with leading zeros before the decimal point or trailing zeros after the decimal should be ignored!
    • Example: '01234' return 'one thousand two hundred and thirty-four'
    • Example: '0.123400' return 'zero point one two three four'
    • Example: '0.0123400' return 'zero point zero one two three four'
    • Example: '0.0' return 'zero'

  • Extreme Large Numbers
    • Example: '42366547562364565786989687455346345764553236534346346346.567345756746456346544534534566456456346546455346546456456456' return 'forty-two septendecillion three hundred and sixty-six sexdecillion five hundred and forty-seven quindecillion five hundred and sixty-two quattuordecillion three hundred and sixty-four tredecillion five hundred and sixty-five duodecillion seven hundred and eighty-six undecillion nine hundred and eighty-nine decillion six hundred and eighty-seven nonillion four hundred and fifty-five octillion three hundred and forty-six septillion three hundred and forty-five sextillion seven hundred and sixty-four quintillion five hundred and fifty-three quadrillion two hundred and thirty-six trillion five hundred and thirty-four billion three hundred and forty-six million three hundred and forty-six thousand three hundred and forty-six point five six seven three four five seven five six seven four six four five six three four six five four four five three four five three four five six six four five six four five six three four six five four six four five five three four six five four six four five six four five six four five six'

  • Consult this list for large number names. Always use the 'short scale' popular in the USA.
    • View List

EXAMPLES:
 ```javascript numberToSpokenEnglish(10);// -> "ten" numberToSpokenEnglish(21);// -> "twenty-one" numberToSpokenEnglish(1.23);// -> "one point two three" numberToSpokenEnglish(45);// -> "forty-five" numberToSpokenEnglish(-45);// -> "negative forty-five" numberToSpokenEnglish(209);// -> "two hundred and nine" numberToSpokenEnglish(219);// -> "two hundred and nineteen" numberToSpokenEnglish(536);// -> "five hundred and thirty-six" numberToSpokenEnglish(10000);// -> "ten thousand" numberToSpokenEnglish(1000001);// -> "one million and one" numberToSpokenEnglish(1000011);// -> "one million and eleven" numberToSpokenEnglish(1000111);// -> "one million one hundred and eleven" numberToSpokenEnglish(1011011);// -> "one million eleven thousand and eleven" numberToSpokenEnglish(1109110);// -> "one million one hundred and nine thousand one hundred and ten" numberToSpokenEnglish(-1.12345);// -> "negative one point one two three four five" numberToSpokenEnglish('-Infinity.12345');// -> "negative infinity point one two three four five" (although not a real number) numberToSpokenEnglish(0);// -> "zero" numberToSpokenEnglish(-0);// -> "negative zero" numberToSpokenEnglish('-0');// -> "negative zero" numberToSpokenEnglish('0');// -> "zero" numberToSpokenEnglish('0.0');// -> "zero" numberToSpokenEnglish('01234');// -> "one thousand two hundred and thirty-four" numberToSpokenEnglish('0.123400');// -> "zero point one two three four" numberToSpokenEnglish('0.0123400');// -> "zero point zero one two three four" numberToSpokenEnglish(100023999);// -> "one hundred million twenty-three thousand nine hundred and ninety-nine" numberToSpokenEnglish(25161045656);// -> 'twenty-five billion one hundred and sixty-one million forty-five thousand six hundred and fifty-six' numberToSpokenEnglish(Infinity);// -> "infinity" numberToSpokenEnglish(-Infinity);// -> "negative infinity" numberToSpokenEnglish('42366547562364565786989687455346345764553236534346346346.567345756746456346544534534566456456346546455346546456456456');// -> "forty-two septendecillion three hundred and sixty-six sexdecillion five hundred and forty-seven quindecillion five hundred and sixty-two quattuordecillion three hundred and sixty-four tredecillion five hundred and sixty-five duodecillion seven hundred and eighty-six undecillion nine hundred and eighty-nine decillion six hundred and eighty-seven nonillion four hundred and fifty-five octillion three hundred and forty-six septillion three hundred and forty-five sextillion seven hundred and sixty-four quintillion five hundred and fifty-three quadrillion two hundred and thirty-six trillion five hundred and thirty-four billion three hundred and forty-six million three hundred and forty-six thousand three hundred and forty-six point five six seven three four five seven five six seven four six four five six three four six five four four five three four five three four five six six four five six four five six three four six five four six four five five three four six five four six four five six four five six four five six" ```
